content.description: You are asked to identify pitch patterns. After a question is announced, you will have ten seconds to read the relevant choices. It is important that you read the choices carefully before the example is played. Each example will be played twice, with a brief pause between playings.
content.question: Which of the following is played?

choices.label: The figure presents a single measure on a staff in Treble clef. There is no Key signature or Time signature. A homophonic chord of three whole notes is shown with pitches E 4, G 4 and C 4.
The figure presents a single measure on a staff in Treble clef. There is no Key signature or Time signature. A homophonic chord of three whole notes is shown with pitches E flat 4, G 4 and C 4.
The figure presents a single measure on a staff in Treble clef. There is no Key signature or Time signature. A homophonic chord of three whole notes is shown with pitches E 4, A 4 and C 4.
The figure presents a single measure on a staff in Treble clef. There is no Key signature or Time signature. A homophonic chord of three whole notes is shown with pitches E flat 4, A flat 4 and C 4.

content.answer: The figure presents a single measure on a staff in Treble clef. There is no Key signature or Time signature. A homophonic chord of three whole notes is shown with pitches E flat 4, G 4 and C 4.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

topic.text: 3.1: Triad and Chord Qualities (M, m, d, A)

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Use symbols and terms to describe features of pitch in performed music, including pitch patterns and relationships, melodic features, chords, harmonic progressions, and cadences.
